etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in William Fulke (d. 1589), theologian and college head. From classical Latin pūtidus rotten, decaying, stinking, foul, base from pūtēre to stink + -idus

definitions: Morally or intellectually corrupt or worthless; base, foul, loathsome; = "putrid".

notes.text: Frequently used as a general term of contempt or disparagement.
